key_title: Key to the species of Vittadinia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Vittadinia
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1999). Vittadinia. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Cypselas without marginal ridges or ribs on the flattened faces
Cypselas with marginal ridges developed and often prominent, flattened faces with or without ribbing
Pappus plumose; cypselas not compressed
Pappus barbellate; cypselas slightly compressed
Flattened faces of cypselas unribbed
Flattened faces of cypselas ribbed
Cypselas 5–6.5 mm long; stems usually branched above base; plants annual
Cypselas 6–11 mm long; stems unbranched above base; plants perennial
Facial ribs of cypselas convergent below the summit of the cypsela body and none or few of the ribs continued through to the summit; marginal ribs commonly fused with adjacent facial ribs
Facial ribs of cypselas not or scarcely convergent, and all or most ribs continued through to summit; marginal ribs rarely fused with adjacent facial ribs
Cypselas hairy throughout, with a mixture of simple hairs and shortly stalked or sessile glands (but glands often confined to apical area)
Cypselas glabrous toward base (apart from callus tuft), upper part rather sparsely hairy, devoid of glandular hairs
Marginal ribs of cypselas glabrous (except near basal tuft), or rarely, with a few small hairs near summit, hairs on cypsela faces all eglandular
Marginal ribs of cypselas covered with hairs similar to those of cypsela faces (but hairs sometimes smaller), glands or glandular hairs often present on cypsela faces
Leaves oblanceolate to elliptic, sometimes with a pair of teeth or lobes toward apex; inner involucral bracts acuminate; cypselas with all facial ribs continued to base

Leaves filiform to narrow-elliptic, entire or with narrow, acute lobes arising well below apex; inner involucral bracts obtuse to acute (or if acuminate then leaves entire and narrow); cypselas with facial ribs convergent toward base
Cypselas with short, thick, clavate hairs on ribs in upper part, glabrous toward base; very rare, in north-west
Cypselas with narrow subclavate or straight blunt hairs between and/or on ribs; Melbourne area and eastern Victoria
Leaves linear to narrow-ovate, usually with 2–6 narrow, acute lateral lobes; cypselas appressed-hairy on lower part; plants usually several-stemmed from base, stems simple or branched
Leaves filiform to narrow-linear, simple, channelled above; cypselas more or less glabrous toward base; plants usually single-stemmed at base, branched above

Eglandular hairs on upper part of cypsela faces with bluntly bifid apices; eglandular hairs on marginal ridges similar to those on faces but markedly smaller or absent but then short glandular hairs present; vegetative parts conspicuously glandular

Eglandular hairs on upper part of cypsela faces entire or minutely and acutely bifid; hairs on marginal ridges of similar length to those of faces (but sometimes incurved); vegetative parts weakly glandular or eglandular
Leaves once or twice trilobed or trisected above a very narrow, petiole-like base, not or hardly folded; involucres less than 6 mm long

Leaves cuneate, oblanceolate or obovate (rarely spathulate and then more or less evenly tapered to base), usually longitudinally folded, entire or with a pair of short lobes toward tip; involucres mostly more than 6 mm long
Indumentum of straight or slightly curved or crisped, spreading to appressed, stiffish hairs, if ever somewhat cottony never completely covering stems, leaves or bracts
Indumentum of fine white cottony hairs, usually covering younger stems, often extending to leaves and involucral bracts
